symptoms: Numbness or tingling in the hands or feet
Sores or cuts that heal slowly or not at all
Numbness or tingling in hands or feet
Frequent skin and/or vaginal yeast infections
feeling very hungry, even after you have eaten
frequent infections, such as urinary tract infections, skin infections, or yeast infections
unexplained weight loss (specific to type 1 diabetes)
pain, numbness, or tingling in the feet or hands (specific to type 2 diabetes)
thirstier than usual or having to urinate more often (specific to gestational diabetes)
Presence of ketones in the urine
Feeling irritable or having other mood changes
Getting a lot of infections, such as gum, skin and vaginal infections
Tingling or loss of feeling in the hands and feet (diabetic neuropathy)
Sores that do not heal well
causes: Type 1 diabetes: autoimmune attack on insulin-producing cells in the pancreas
Type 2 diabetes: insulin resistance and high blood sugar due to genetics and lifestyle factors
Type 1.5 diabetes: autoimmune condition similar to Type 1, occurring in adults
Gestational diabetes: hormonal changes during pregnancy causing insulin resistance
Type 1 diabetes develops when the immune system destroys the insulin-producing beta cells in the pancreas.
Type 2 diabetes develops when the pancreas doesn’t produce enough insulin and the body has trouble using insulin (insulin resistance).
Gestational diabetes occurs when the body can’t make the extra insulin needed during pregnancy.
Genetic factors and environmental triggers may contribute to the development of type 1 diabetes.
Obesity, lack of physical activity, and poor diet are significant contributors to type 2 diabetes.
Certain medications and endocrine diseases can also lead to diabetes.
Insufficient insulin production by the pancreas
Lifestyle factors such as inadequate exercise and excessive weight gain
treatment_options: Medications (e.g., insulin, metformin, GLP-1 receptor agonists)
Insulin therapy for Type 1 and Type 1.5 diabetes
Oral medications for Type 2 diabetes including metformin, sulfonylureas, DPP-4 inhibitors, GLP-1 receptor agonists, SGLT2 inhibitors
Dietary changes and exercise for managing blood sugar levels
Lifestyle changes including diet and exercise.
Insulin therapy for type 1 diabetes and some type 2 diabetes patients
Regular monitoring of blood glucose levels
Medications to control blood glucose levels
diagnosis_methods: Oral glucose tolerance test (for gestational diabetes)
Routine blood sugar tests for gestational diabetes
risk_factors: Ethnicity (e.g., African American, Hispanic, Native American)
High blood pressure, high cholesterol, or high triglycerides
Certain racial and ethnic backgrounds (African American, Hispanic or Latino American, Asian American)
Certain ethnic backgrounds (African American, American Indian, Asian American, Hispanic, Latino, or Pacific Islander).
Age (more common in people older than 40)
Certain ethnic backgrounds (e.g., Black, Hispanic, American Indian, Asian American)
Presence of autoantibodies in type 1 diabetes
Age (most common in middle age or later)
Ethnic background (higher prevalence in Native Americans, African Americans, and Hispanics)
prevention: Healthy diet low in fats and sugars
Eat a healthy diet (e.g., Mediterranean diet)
Get physically active (aim for 30 minutes a day)
Achieve and maintain a healthy weight
Regular physical activity (at least 150 minutes per week)
Healthy eating with a focus on fruits, vegetables, and whole grains
Avoiding saturated and trans fats, and refined carbohydrates
Regular blood sugar monitoring for those with prediabetes
Monitoring blood sugar levels if at risk
extracted_data.prognosis: The prognosis for diabetes varies greatly depending on the type of diabetes, management of the condition, age at diagnosis, presence of other health conditions, and complications. Chronic high blood sugar can lead to severe complications, but with proper management, individuals can live healthy lives.

family_history_impact.inheritance_pattern: Multifactorial inheritance with contributions from multiple genes and environmental factors.
family_history_impact.risk_increase: Family history significantly increases the risk of developing type 2 diabetes, with higher risk associated with the number of affected relatives.
family_history_impact.age_of_onset_influence: Family history can influence the age of onset, with those having a family history potentially developing diabetes at a younger age.
family_history_impact.severity_influence: Family history may affect the severity of the disease, with some individuals experiencing more severe symptoms or complications.
family_history_impact.screening_recommendations: Family members of individuals with diabetes should be screened regularly for diabetes, especially if they have additional risk factors.

hereditary_factors: Specific gene mutations associated with MODY and neonatal diabetes
Genetic mutations associated with MODY and neonatal diabetes
Family history of Type 1 and Type 2 diabetes
Genetic predisposition to Type 1 and Type 2 diabetes
Specific genes associated with insulin resistance and beta-cell function
Genetic predisposition to type 1 and type 2 diabetes.
Monogenic diabetes due to single gene mutations.
Genetic predisposition to type 1 and type 2 diabetes
Presence of diabetes-related autoantibodies in family members
Genetic mutations associated with insulin resistance
At least 150 DNA variations associated with increased risk
Common genetic variations present in both affected and unaffected individuals
extracted_data.genetic_risk_assessment: Family history is a strong indicator of genetic risk for type 2 diabetes, and understanding this can help in early detection and prevention strategies.
